facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1096 of 1963

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1096 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment dated January 3, 1961 of the Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 114 of 1956

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment dated January 3, 1961 of the Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 114 of 1956 L2Sup/65-13 N.

facts.text: Madras High Court answered the question whether the reassessment under s. 34 of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 completed on 30th June, 1953 for the year 1944-45 is valid in the negative

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave directed against the judgment of the Madras High Court answering the question whether the reassessment under s. 34  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922  companypleted on 30th June, 1953 for the year 1944-45 is valid in the negative.

facts.text: The respondent is a Hindu undivided family

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are as follows The respondent, hereinafter referred to as the assessee is a Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: For the assessment years 1944-45 and 1945-46, the assessee filed no returns under s. 22 of the Indian Income Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1944-45 and 1945-46, the assessee filed numberreturns under s. 22 of the Indian Income Tax Act, hereinafter referred to as the Act, number were any numberices issued under s. 22 2  of the Act.

facts.text: No notices issued under s. 22(2) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: ...the assessee filed numberreturns under s. 22 of the Indian Income Tax Act, hereinafter referred to as the Act, number were any numberices issued under s. 22 2  of the Act.

facts.text: On April 3, 1948, the Income Tax Officer issued notices under S. 34 for both the assessment years

anchor.surface_text: On April 3, 1948, the Income Tax Officer issued numberices under S. 34 for both the assessment years. At that time it was number necessary to obtain sanction of the Commissioner of Income Tax and numbere was obtained.

facts.text: At that time it was not necessary to obtain sanction of the Commissioner of Income Tax and none was obtained

anchor.surface_text: At that time it was number necessary to obtain sanction of the Commissioner of Income Tax and numbere was obtained.

facts.text: The assessee filed a return for the assessment year 1944-45 on September 4, 1948, showing an income of Rs. 4,053 which was below the HUF taxable limit of Rs. 7,200

anchor.surface_text: The assessee filed a return for the assessment year 1944-45 on September 4, 1948, showing an income of Rs. 4,053 which was below the HUF taxable limit of Rs. 7,200.

facts.text: The assessee also filed a return for the assessment year 1945-46

anchor.surface_text: The assessee also filed a return for the assessment year 1945-46.

facts.text: The Income Tax Officer dropped proceedings for 1944-45 as infructuous

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Income Tax Officer dropped proceedings for 1944-45 as in fructuous, but for the assessment year 1945-46, he passed an order on October 27, 1950,...

facts.text: For the assessment year 1945-46, Income Tax Officer passed an order on October 27, 1950, determining the net taxable income as Rs. 1,20,603

anchor.surface_text: ...but for the assessment year 1945-46, he passed an order on October 27, 1950, determining the net taxable income as Rs. 1,20,603.

facts.text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and then to the Appellate Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant ,Commissioner and then appealed to the Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: On November 19, 1952, the Appellate Tribunal allowed the appeal in part

anchor.surface_text: On November 19, 1952, the Appellate Tribunal allowed the appeal in part.

facts.text: Tribunal held that out of a total profit of Rs. 79,760 arising from the sale of certain properties, only Rs. 33,000 was assessable in 1945-46 and Rs. 46,760 in 1944-45

anchor.surface_text: It held that out of a total profit of Rs. 79,760 arising from the sale of certain properties, only Rs. 33,000 was assessable in the assessment year 1945-46 and Rs. 46,760 was assessable in the assessment year 1944-45.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal observed that the Income Tax Officer is at liberty to take such action as he may be advised about the assessee's liability for 1944-45

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal ,observed thus in the order The Income Tax Officer is at liberty to take such action as he may be advised about the assessees liability for the earlier year 1944-45.

facts.text: On February 27, 1953, after having obtained the sanction of the Commissioner, the Income Tax Officer issued a notice under S. 34 for 1944-45

anchor.surface_text: On February 27, 1953, after having obtained the sanction of the Commissioner, the Income Tax Officer issued a numberice purporting to be under S. 34 of the Act in respect of the assessment year 1944-45.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer passed an order on June 30, 1953, assessing the total income as Rs. 51,523

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer paged an order on June 30, 1953, assessing the total income as Rs. 51,523.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner affirmed the order

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner affirmed the order.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that action under s.34(1)(a) was valid and second proviso to s.34(3) applicable

anchor.surface_text: He held that the action of the Income Tax Officer in starting proceedings under s. 34 1   a  was valid. He further held that in view of the finding of the Appellate Tribunal...

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal affirmed the assessment on the ground that second proviso to s.34(3) applied

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal, without going into the question whether s. 34   1    a  companyld be invoked by the Revenue, affirmed the assessment on the ground that the second proviso to s. 34 3  of the Act, as amended, applied.

facts.text: At the instance of the assessee, Appellate Tribunal referred the question to High Court

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the assessee, the Appellate Tribunal referred the question set out in the beginning of the judgment.

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the negative

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, as already stated, answered the question in the negative.

facts.text: High Court held that the return filed on September 4, 1948 was result of invalid notice but return itself could not be ignored

anchor.surface_text: It held that numberwithstanding that the return filed by the assessee on September 4, 1948, was the result of an invalid numberice, the return itself companyld number be ignored or disregarded by the Department,...

facts.text: Appellant counsel submits that the return was not voluntary and made in pursuance of invalid notice, must be treated as invalid

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Rajagopala Sastri, the learned companynsel for the appellant, submits that the return was number voluntary and as it was made in pursuance of an invalid numberice, must also be treated as invalid.

issues.text: whether the reassessment under s. 34 of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 completed on 30th June, 1953 for the year 1944-45 is valid

anchor.surface_text: answering the question whether the reassessment under s. 34  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922  completed on 30th June, 1953 for the year 1944-45 is valid in the negative. The relevant facts are as follows The respondent, hereinafter referred to as the assessee is a Hindu undivided family.

issues.text: whether the return dated September 4, 1948, can be treated as valid return under s. 22(3) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The short question which arises in this case is whether the return dated September 4, 1948, can be treated as valid return under s. 22 3  of the Act. Section 22 3  is in the following terms 22 3 . If any person has not furnished a return within the time allowed by or under sub-section  1  or sub-section  2 , or having furnished a return under either of those sub- sections,

issues.text: whether a return under s. 22(3) must be voluntary or suo motu

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri says that it is further implicit in s. 22 3  that the return must be voluntary. We are unable to appreciate that every return made under S. 22 3  must be a voluntary return, in the sense that it must be suo motu. If a return is made in pursuance to a general notice under s. 22 1 , or a special notice under s. 22 2 , it is a return made voluntary but not suo motu.

issues.text: whether the second proviso to sub-s. (3) of s. 34, as amended by Amendment Act of 1953, applies to overcome the time-limit

anchor.surface_text: under s. 34 1   a  was valid. He further held that in view of the finding of the Appellate Tribunal that the Income Tax Officer would be at liberty to take action about the assessees liability to tax for 1944-45 assessment, the second proviso to sub-s.  3  of s. 34, as amended by Amend- ment Act of 1953, was applicable and consequently the time- limit specified in s. 34 would not be applicable.

arguments.claim: The return filed on September 4, 1948 was not voluntary and as it was made in pursuance of an invalid notice, must also be treated as invalid. No assessment could be made on its basis.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Rajagopala Sastri, the learned counsel for the appellant, submits that the return was not voluntary and as it was made in pursuance of an invalid notice, must also be treated as invalid.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mberice issued on 3rd April 1948 and return filed on 4th September 1948 being valid the proceedings thus initiated came to an end on 27th October, 195

arguments.court_reasoning: Every return under s.22(3) need not be voluntary or suo motu; can be made in response to notice under s.22(1), s.22(2) or deemed under s.34 as s.22(2).

arguments.claim: The case of Ranchhodas Karsondas is distinguishable.

anchor.surface_text: He says that noassessment could be made on its basis. He further says that the case of Ranchhodas Karsondas1 is distinguishable.

arguments.claim: The proposition in statement of case admits return was valid; new point on return invalidity cannot be urged at this stage.

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellant not raising new point; statement follows assertion notice valid, but elsewhere states return not voluntary.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees return valid under s.22(3); assessment possible before time limit.

arguments.claim: Return result of invalid notice but return itself cannot be ignored; cannot issue further s.34(1)(a) assuming omission under s.22; Ranchhodas governs.

anchor.surface_text: It held that notwithstanding that the return filed by the assessee on September 4, 1948, was the result of an invalid notice, the return itself could not be ignored or disregarded by the Department, and the Department cannot issue a further notice under s. 34 1   a  of the Act on the assumption that there had been an omission or failure on the part of the assessee to make a return of his income under s. 22.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tinguishable. The learned companynsel for the assessee raises an objection to this new point being urgred at this stage. He points out that in the sta

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees return valid under s.22(3) even if prompted by notice.

arguments.claim: Return dated September 4, 1948 is valid return under s.22(3).

anchor.surface_text: The short question which arises in this case is whether the return dated September 4, 1948, can be treated as valid return under s. 22 3  of the Act.

arguments.claim: Return under s.22(3) must be filed before time in s.34(3); here satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of S. 34 3 , as it stood in 1949, assessment could have been made at least up to March 31, 1949, if the return was valid. Therefore, it may be implied... that the return must be filed before the time mentioned in S. 34 3 . This condition is, however, satisfied in this case.

arguments.claim: s.22(3) does not require return to be voluntary or suo motu; can be in response to notice.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri says that it is further implicit in s. 22 3  that the return must be voluntary. We are unable to appreciate that every return made under S. 22 3  must be a voluntary return, in the sense that it must be suo motu. If a return is made in pursuance to a general notice under s. 22 1 , or a special notice under s. 22 2 , it is a return made voluntary but not suo motu.

arguments.claim: Return in response to s.34 notice deemed under s.22(2) and thus under s.22(3).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both types of returns are under s. 22 3  of the Act. In the first type of cases it is directly under s. 22 3 . In case of a notice under s. 34, it is deemed to be notice under s. 22 2  and the return deemed to be a return under s. 22 3 .

arguments.claim: Pratap Singh case not contrary; there prior returns filed, here no prior return so s.22(3) applies.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri however, says that this Court proceeded on a contrary view in Commissioner of Income-tax Bihar and Orissa v. Maharaja Pratap Singh Bahadur of Gidhaur1 . ... But in the present case the assessee had never filed a return under s. The first return he filed was in response to notice under s. 34, but he could have filed this return even without a notice under s. 34, for the four years prescribed by s. 34 3 had not expired.

arguments.claim: If notice under s.34 bad, return not necessarily bad; reject R.K. Das Co.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri further contends that if the notice under s. 34 is held to be bad, it must follow that the return made in pursuance of it must also be treated as bad. We are satisfied that there is no substance in this contention. The decision of the Calcutta High Court in R. K. Das Co. Commissioner of Income-Tax West Bengal1 certainly supports Mr. Sastris contention but, with respect, we are unable to agree with the reasoning of the High Court.

arguments.claim: This Court in Pratap Singh assumed fresh notices could be issued because prior returns existed, unlike here.

anchor.surface_text: These observations certainly show that this Court assumed that fresh notices could have been issued in that case. Mr. Sastri says that the Department has done exactly what the Supreme Court indicated in that case should be done. But, apart from the fact that there is no discussion on the question of the validity of the return, it is possible to say that on the facts in that case fresh notices could have been issued.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: also one where income had I escaped assessment. Clause  a  of section 34 1  was therefore applicable and the second numberice under section 34 was giv

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts differ: prior returns in Pratap, none here allowing s.22(3) return.

holdings.text: The return dated September 4, 1948 was a valid return under s. 22(3) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both types of returns are under s. 22 3  of the Act. In the first type of cases it is directly under s. 22 3 . In case of a numberice under s. 34, it is deemed to be numberice under s. 22 2  and the return deemed to be a return under s. 22 3 . From the language of s. 22 3 , we are unable to say that the return dated September 4, 1948, was number a return within s. 22 3 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.34 notice deemed s.22(2) notice; return in response deemed under s.22(3) as no prior return filed and filed before assessment time limit

holdings.text: Every return under s.22(3) need not be voluntary or suo motu; can be in response to notice under s.22(1), s.22(2) or s.34

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri says that it is further implicit in s. 22 3  that the return must be voluntary. We are unable to appreciate that every return made under S. 22 3  must be a voluntary return, in the sense that it must be suo motu. If a return is made in pursuance to a general numberice under s. 22 1 , or a special numberice under s. 22 2 , it is a return made voluntary but number suo motu.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of s.22(3) permits returns before assessment; examples of non-suo motu returns under s.22(1)/(2) are voluntary yet prompted

holdings.text: The reassessment under s.34 completed on June 30, 1953 for 1944-45 is invalid

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave directed against the judgment of the Madras High Court answering the question whether the reassessment under s. 34  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922  companypleted on 30th June, 1953 for the year 1944-45 is valid in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid s.22(3) return filed precludes invocation of s.34(1)(a) for omission/failure to file under s.22; no escaped assessment on that ground

holdings.text: If notice under s.34 is invalid, the return made in pursuance thereof is not invalid and can be treated under s.22(3)

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri further contends that if the notice under s. 34 is held to be bad, it must follow that the return made in pursuance of it must also be treated as bad. We are satisfied that there is no substance in this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Return stands on its own under s.22(3) language; ITO could assess on it under s.23; disapproves R.K. Das (Cal HC)

holdings.text: A return under s.22(3) must be filed before expiry of time limit in s.34(3) but condition satisfied here

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of S. 34 3 , as it stood in 1949, assessment companyld have been made at least up to March 31, 1949, if the return was valid. Therefore, it may be implied... that the return must be filed before the time mentioned in S. 34 3 . This companydition is, however, satisfied in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Implied from s.34(3) time limits and precedents (Santosha Nadar, Bhagwandas); return filed Sept 1948 before March 1949 limit

holdings.text: Facts distinguishable from Pratap Singh case as no prior returns filed here allowing s.22(3) treatment

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri however, says that this Court proceeded on a company- trary view in Commissioner of Income-tax Bihar and Orissa v. Maharaja Pratap Singh Bahadur of Gidhaur1 . ... But in the present case the assessee had never filed a return under s. The first return he filed was in response to notice under s. 34, but he could have filed this return even without a notice under s. 34, for the four years prescribed by s. 34 3 had not expired.

holdings.reasoning_summary: In Pratap prior returns filed under s.22; fresh s.34 returns not revisable under s.22(3); here first return ever, timely under s.22(3)

holdings.text: Appellant is not raising any new point by arguing return invalidity

anchor.surface_text: In our,opinion the appellant is number raising any new point. It is true that in the above cited proposition the appellant says that the return is valid but this follows the assertion that the numberice issued on April 3, 1948 is valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statement of case elsewhere notes return not voluntary; consistent with notice validity argument

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri further companytends that if the numberice under s. 34 is held to be bad, it must follow that the return made in pursuance of it must also be treated as bad. We are satisfied that there is numbersubstance in this companytention. The decision of the Calcutta High Court in R. K. Das Co. Commissioner of Income-Tax West Bengal 1 certainly supports Mr. Sastris companytention but, with respect, we are unable to agree with the reasoning of the High Court. anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both types of returns are under s. 22 3  of the Act. In the first type of cases it is directly under s. 22 3 . In case of a numberice under s. 34, it is deemed to be numberice under s. 22 2  and the return deemed to be a return under s. 22 3 . From the language of s. 22 3 , we are unable to say that the return dated September 4, 1948, was number a return within s. 22 3 .

Mr. Sastri further companytends that if the numberice under s. 34 is held to be bad, it must follow that the return made in pursuance of it must also be treated as bad. We are satisfied that there is numbersubstance in this companytention. The decision of the Calcutta High Court in R. K. Das Co. Commissioner of Income-Tax West Bengal 1 certainly supports Mr. Sastris companytention but, with respect, we are unable to agree with the reasoning of the High Court. Apart from the fact that this Court did number approve of this decision in Ranchhoddas Karsondass case , we are unable to appreciate that if the Income Tax Officer had based his assessment on the return treating it to be a return under s. 22 3 .

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri says that it is further implicit in s. 22 3  that the return must be voluntary. We are unable to appreciate that every return made under S. 22 3  must be a voluntary return, in the sense that it must be suo motu. If a return is made in pursuance to a general numberice under s. 22 1 , or a special numberice under s. 22 2 , it is a return made voluntary but number suo motu.

Mr. Sastri further companytends that if the numberice under s. 34 is held to be bad, it must follow that the return made in pursuance of it must also be treated as bad. We are satisfied that there is numbersubstance in this companytention. The decision of the Calcutta High Court in R. K. Das Co. Commissioner of Income-Tax West Bengal 1 certainly supports Mr. Sastris companytention but, with respect, we are unable to agree with the reasoning of the High Court. anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave directed against the judgment of the Madras High Court answering the question whether the reassessment under s. 34  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922  companypleted on 30th June, 1953 for the year 1944-45 is valid in the negative.

Mr. Sastri further companytends that if the numberice under s. 34 is held to be bad, it must follow that the return made in pursuance of it must also be treated as bad.
